releasenotes/notes/microversion-1.24-mul.message:
That's not quite right. There's a few examples in the feature release note that may make it more clear: https://docs.openstack.org/releasenotes/nova/rocky.html#new-features (search for "1.24" in the document)

From that:

+    Get all providers that are associated with agg1 OR agg2:
+    ?member_of=in:agg1,agg2
+    Get all providers that are associated with agg1 and ANY OF (agg2, agg3):
+    ?member_of=agg1&member_of=in:agg2,agg3
+    Get all providers that are associated with ANY OF (agg1, agg2) AND are also
+    associated with ANY OF (agg3, agg4):
+    ?member_of=in:agg1,agg2&member_of=in:agg3,agg4
Please check current description. Hopefully it's slightly better now.

This example is a bit misleading because you would presumably get the same results without include the 'in:'.

Or at least that would be my expectation based on what microversion 1.24 is: being able to use multiple member_of (of whatever form) in a single query.

That's why it's important for user to understand when to use and when to not use 'in:' keyword. Without it, listing resource providers would work exactly as it worked before. But when 'in:' keyword is in use, then user has to be aware that the results will be returned using new, 1.24, functionality. In other words, 'in:' HAS TO BE USED with every other occurrence of --aggregate-uuid option if user wants the results based on microversion 1.24 and HAS TO BE SKIPPED otherwise. I understand that is it very confusing, but for now, I do not have any other idea for this implementation.

The examples are mostly copied from: https://review.opendev.org/#/c/561315/16/releasenotes/notes/multi-member-of-4f9518a96652c0c6.yaml
Again, it's not clear what the 'in:' is doing here, other than being confusing.

As above:
'in:' keyword used - 1.24>
no 'in:' keyword - <1.24

Okay, then one solution to that is to drop backward compatibility, so when microversion 1.24 is in use, using multiple --aggregate-uuid would work exactly as using multiple member_of query parameters.

Another way is to introduce new option / flag - then I would need some proposals how to name it.

But that's not how selecting a microversion works. You have to explicitly declare your microversion:

    --os-placement-api-version 1.24

I don't think you can use int() here because it's in a SQLAlchemy expression. We could probably use int() later because it appears that a Decimal casts to a string which we can then cast to an int.

I thought it was safer to do it here because:
1. The returned type is defined by the database driver, so we don't know for sure what it is or what its interface is to cast it. A SQLA cast abstracts us from that.
2. Passing around a random database-specific type which folks will probably assume is an int felt like a bit of a landmine.

I'll hopefully write some tests later which should make it easier to play with the above if we're interested. I'm slightly nervous that the tests might involve SQLite and return a different type, which would be annoying.

That's actually already covered in the quota db tests[1] because get_reservations_for_resources() is just a wrapper for get_total_reservations_map()[2]. I'd already seen these tests, but I was assuming you'd want a test that failed without this change, but passed with the change, and for that we need MySQL.

However, I'm more than happy to go with the existing test! I think it's justified because:

* The existing test demonstrates that the change doesn't regress on SQLite
* The existing test already implicitly asserts the type of the returned value
* Manual testing demonstrates that the change fixes the issue on MySQL
* Tempest testing demonstrates that the change doesn't regress MySQL in general
* The lack of fine-grained unit/functional testing on MySQL isn't confined to this issue and can reasonably be addressed separately

Shall I just update the commit message and we're good to go?

[1] https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/src/commit/5f6fbcb155e19d0a46cef0e7bbfee553f0472ef3/neutron/tests/unit/db/quota/test_api.py#L242-L255

I think (and I see the evidence in the test in test_host.py) you're using the word "loader[s]" — here and throughout — to loosely refer to both the OVMF binary blob and the "VARS" (VARiableS) file[*], OVMF_CODE.secboot.fd and OVMF_VARS.secboot.fd, respectively.

However, as you notice in the guest XML, in libvirt parlance "loader" XML element is used for the OVMF binary blob; while the VARS is handled by the "nvram" element.

[*] The VARS file a non-volatile memory store that contain OVMF "variables" e.g. the keys and certificates enrolled, and other boot-level customizations.

I'd rewrite the above sentence to the effect that the 'pc' (and 'q35') aliases map on to the latest QEMU version that is installed on the host. 

The version you cite above (typo: "pc-1440fx-5.1" --> "pc-i440fx-5.1") is based on Fedora-33:

    $> rpm -q qemu-system-x86
    qemu-system-x86-5.1.0-7.fc33.x86_64

    $> qemu-system-x86_64 -machine help | grep "alias of pc"
    pc                   Standard PC (i440FX + PIIX, 1996) (alias of pc-i440fx-5.1)
    q35                  Standard PC (Q35 + ICH9, 2009) (alias of pc-q35-5.1)

Here too: "provided by QEMU" can give the impression that the distros pick their OVMF binaries directly from QEMU. As you see, QEMU only provides the firmware interface (and templates), and each distro customizes them as per their EDK2/OVMF builds.  For example SUSE (SLES) generates far more variants (for no good reason, actually) of OVMF binaries than any of Debian or Fedora.  Also each OVMF binary is unique to a given distro, as they're signed by a distro-specific key.

So, suggest to use:

    Inspect the firmware metadata files shipped provided by a Linux distro's 
    OVMF/EDK2 package to retrieve details [...]

s/UEFI loaders/UEFI binaries/

(I think you mean, only UEFI, but not—yet—SeaBIOS, et al)
looks good to me for a follow-up

swift/cli/relinker.py.message:
Nice, I wonder if we could have a:

 def check

Which might just be a Relink with a dry_run option? or if it's just checking existance of the links then a new child clas.

yes, maybe.

Where I ended up on this patch chain is a single chunk of code that finds what files exist in old dir *and which need to be linked*. Currently we try to link to anything that exists, and it's currently hard to be sure when all *necessary* links exist. 

In the new world my thinking is that a 'check' step could simply be a relink step that found no links needed.

Then I realised that when cleaning up, if we found files that need relinking, why not relink them right there? So a cleanup step becomes a relink step that removes files if all is looking good.

So, the process becomes (after everything on this patch chain):
1. relink - reports how many links were created
2, repeat relink until no links created
3. move ring to next part power
4. relink with cleanup=True - report if any links were created (unexpected)
5. maybe repeat 4 until no links created just to be sure
Oh yeah, and we lost this part -- but it's probably for the best?
I think we may need to change some things in partitions_filter and hook_post_partition if we want relink to run on a increased ring

agree it would be useful to be able to relink after increase, but before if we had multiple policies, some in prepared state and some in increased state then relink would only select those in prepared state - that still seems like a useful feature, so you could be relinking one policy and cleaning up another without the relinking straying into the clean-up policy.

How about we have the --policy override the part power checks so that the tool *can* relink a policy whose part power has been increased, but by default wouldn't?
hmmm, I want to check that

fwiw, we had to actively work around this last time, setting up a separate tmpdir with the old ring, so we could relink again before cleaning up. With the new cleanup checks, I don't think that will be so necessary, but I could see someone wanting some warm & fuzzies by doing a process like

1. prepare increase
2. relink
3. increase
4. relink again
5. clean up
6. finish increase

Thanks for fixing this -- yeah, I can see how running relink on a next_part_power==part_power ring is going to be a little fraught and definitely out of scope for this change.

The --policy override idea is interesting, though I wonder if we'd actually want it to be a separate, explicit flag. I'm also realizing we may want a --clear-state flag or something to nuke the state file(s) at the start of a run. Currently, I think a running relink a second time will trivially succeed without actually looking at any partitions.
We're not putting this in self.stats?
So when we're running against a single device, this will include the device in the path. Different, but good.

Does this actually need to be a property? Seems like we only use it here. Or is that going to change with the next patch?

It just seems weird that we'll mutate this as we're processing...

no it is not necessary, will fix

If we were to get rid of the partial callbacks and make them all methods of this class then self.policy would be used.

So this is a bit of a change -- we use this to determine whether to log about not finding a policy, but

* previously we wanted to make sure we actually *found data* in at least one policy, where
* now we'll just make sure *there exists a policy* in the appropriate state.

I think I like this better, though.
I'm not sure there is a change - see line 265 in Base - we set found_policy=True before visiting any data dirs.
You're right, my bad -- I was thinking of the relinked counter.

Oh, interesting... so --files-per-second means different things for relink vs cleanup...

openstackclient/image/v2/image.py.message:
Now we use low-level REST API to talk with image server, so I think the paging logic is not necessary, we can put these filters(marker, limit, sort) to image server directly.

https://developer.openstack.org/api-ref/image/v2/index.html#show-images

I don't think we should add hard check at here, that break the usage "image list --sort checksum", even if that looks impossible, but we should keep backwards compatible, the alternative is adding the keys list into help message of '--sort' option, then pass the arguments to glance API directly, like we do in current master. Not prefect, but smooth.

The example of backward incompatibility is "image list --sort checksum", it works in master, but breaks in PS4, because "checksum" is not in SORT_KEY_VALUES. Actually "--sort" option is not ignored in master code, we sort the result in client side, sorting by "checksum" is supported, don't break it.

PS5 looks good to me, expose the capability of Glance API directly, and no limitation, if Glance support more sort key in the future, we don't have to change osc code, help message is just weak dependence.

Thanks for review :)
not sure the backward compatibility if for what, this is borrowed from glanceclient, actually, in master, we don't pass the sort arguments to glance API directly, we just ignore that and sort the result in client side. and in glance API side, the supported sort keys are also SORT_KEY_VALUES, I am OK to change this to pass the arguments directly to glance api, but that may cause a unnecessary api call if we specified a invalid sort key.
Now, we make --limit work with or without --marker option, and sort and filter images in client side, the code looks good to me, thank you.

playbooks/roles/jitsi-meet/files/jitsi-m.message: It looks like the SSL files are getting mounted to /etc/letsencrypt though, not /config (I don't see anything we mount under /config).
So... is this even used now?

It is still used for providing the ssl cert and key to the container. We manage that with acme.sh on the host side and it gets bind mounted into the container via this mechanism. We could probably tighten the paths up to limit this to the keys and certs but one thing at a time.

The host side is /var/jitsi-meet/web which is mounted at /config in the container (https://opendev.org/opendev/system-config/src/branch/master/playbooks/roles/letsencrypt-create-certs/handlers/restart_jitsi_meet.yaml#L8-L24). While we mount ${CONFIG}/web/letsencrypt:/etc/letsencrypt that appears to be an empty dir and isn't helpful. The certs are all at /var/jitsi-meet/web/keys on the host and /config/keys in the container.

## Presenting status information

Here are a few examples of how to present useful information with the `status` action and the [jq][jq] utility.

* Querying for `online` and `standby` parameter values:

    juju run-action --wait hacluster/leader status \
       --format json | jq '.[] | {(.UnitId):.results.result | fromjson \

tools/setup-lvm-loopdev/setup-lvm-loopde.message:
snapcraft.yaml also contains a setup-lvm-loopdev service so that a loop device is allocated for the backing file after a reboot.

AFAIK there is no guarantee that the same loopback device number will be available after reboot because, for example, other snaps could be installed/removed on this system which would change which devices get allocated to them.

I think we should avoid a filter that's specific to just one device or, alternatively, force a re-rendering of the LVM config when setup-lvm-loopdev service runs and dynamically allocates a loop device with some number.

Unit test should be deterministic. It is not a good idea to change what is tested dynamically. In this case, you need two types of tests (for tm_isdst True and False) instead of using the condition.

The problem with this test is that we depend on a sel.client.get that returns the *current* daylight/standard time at the time of this test execution.   Unless we can inject the current date to that request, it'll always return the *current* daylight/standard time.   My initial user test would simply make sure that on DST, we get +10 and on ST we get +11.  There're no other ways of testing that unless we modify the initial client request to post a date to the form and validate it returns the expected value for that date ...   What else can we do ?
To be more deterministic, so that you don't do a catch all, perhaps simply change the else to an elif

So how would you do this ?   I mean, this test gets an URL and makes sure there's a given string in it... Without this test, we have to either rewrite everything or find a more elegant solution ... but I know, this tests could fail when we change from EST to EDT or something like that.

I don't think that's what Mr. Motoki meant.   We have to be able to test a specific date to see if daylight saving times is applied or not on that timezone.  Putting an elif, an else or whatever here won't solve that issue.   This test isn't good (I know it from the beginning) but other than rewritting the whole test as well as adding a date field that we can use to push the date we want to test to the _sorted_tz function in order to validate if the returned value is the expected one is the only other GOOD way of testing this.   And I'm not sure doing that worths the hassle ... I might just remove that test and go on with life .
Without calling directly the functions from views.py or injecting date in the forms, this is not possible .  Should I simply remove the australia timezone check ?

What I would like to suggest is to cover both cases of tm_isdst True and False. You can do this by mocking time.localtime method. I am not sure the result depends on the result of tm_isdst or not now, so my comment might be wrong. However, the current approach means that if someone in non DST timezone L.32 is never tested and vice versa.

Although I am okay to drop Australian timezone check, could you add a test code to cover you change? It means if you are in timezone with DST, DST string is used and otherwise non-DST timezone string is used. In addition, for areas without DST, what is the expected behavior?

Well in order to do that, I would have to modify the _sort_timezone function wouldn't I ?  The function only return UTC +11:00 or UTC +10:00 which I kind of tested with my initial test but it would only be tested when the date was set to the proper date.   I'm not sure to understand your mock comment as I would still have to mock the other function wouldn't I ?

What I think is to mock datetime.today() function in forms.py.
We can setup the mock to return Jan 1 (non DST) and Aug 1 (DST). By this way we can test DST and non-DST cases.
Does it work for you?

Note that we cannot mock datetime.today directly (as mock can't set attributes of built-in/extension type). If you go to this route, you need to introduce a shim function which just calls datetime.today().

It's not yet documented and I think it's still under discussion to make it permanent, but Tacker is often facing issues to support new features without latest commits of them.

Sorry, I was wrong.
This method is needed for the following reasons:

* `tacker/tests/unit/vnflcm/test_vnflcm_driver.py` uses FakeVNFMPlugin defined in this file (test_nfvo_plugin.py) as mock, and I wrote test method for scaling cnf based on other method.
* In scale operation in VnfLcmDriver, `VNFMPlugin._update_vnf_scaling()` method is called in:

  * VnfLcmDriver._vnf_scale_post()

If I don't add `_update_vnf_scaling` to FakeVNFMPlugin, there will be no method to call, so I added `_update_vnf_scaling()` to FakeVNFMPlugin in this file.
I think using the FakeVNFMPlugin in `test_nfvo_plugin.py` is subtle, but refactoring this has a big impact and I think it's a future work.

manifests/function/minio/certificate.yam.message: What templates these values? This resource would be delivered directly to Kubernetes since it's outside of the Helm chart.

> Are you saying these extra variables I added will not be used? If so I can probably hard code them and then we will need to override with kustomize.

Yep, you've got the right idea. Since this file is packaged outside of the Helm chart, Helm won't be templating it. We can just use Kustomize to pull those values from the HelmRelease file where the values overrides are specified.

In values.yaml I added:

tls:
  enabled: true
  certSecret: minio-tls-api
  publicCrt: tls.crt
  privateKey: tls.key
  issuerName: ca-clusterissuer
  issuerKind: ClusterIssuer
  commonName: minio

The underlying helm chart includes:

tls:
  enabled: false
  certSecret: ""
  publicCrt: public.crt
  privateKey: private.key

I added the 

issuerName
issuerKind
commonName

myself for compatibility with cert-manager.

Are you saying these extra variables I added will not be used? If so I can probably hard code them and then we will need to override with kustomize.

> > Are you saying these extra variables I added will not be used? If so I can probably hard code them and then we will need to override with kustomize.
> 
> Yep, you've got the right idea. Since this file is packaged outside of the Helm chart, Helm won't be templating it. We can just use Kustomize to pull those values from the HelmRelease file where the values overrides are specified.

Thanks, changes made.
